headline: Challah Bread
description: Challah bread is traditional Jewish egg bread made with yeast and sweetened with honey. It's beautiful braided and topped with sesame or poppy seeds.

video.description: See how to make traditional Jewish egg bread.
video.name: Challah I

name: Challah Bread
recipeIngredient: 2.5 cups warm water (110 degrees F/45 degrees C)

recipeInstructions.text: Pour warm water into a large bowl; sprinkle yeast over water. Let stand until yeast softens and begins to form a creamy foam, about 5 minutes.
Beat in honey, oil, 2 eggs, and salt. Add flour, 1 cup at a time, beating after each addition until dough has pulled together.
Turn it out onto a lightly floured surface and knead until smooth and elastic.
Place dough in a large, lightly-oiled bowl and turn to coat.
Cover with a towel and let rise in a warm place until doubled in volume, about 1 1/2 hours.
Punch down dough and turn onto a lightly floured surface. Divide in half and knead each half for 5 minutes or so, adding flour as needed to keep it from getting sticky.
Divide each half into thirds and roll into a long snake about 1 1/2 inches in diameter.

Pinch the ends of the three snakes together firmly and braid from middle. Either leave as a braid or form into a round braided loaf by bringing ends together, curving the braid into a circle, and pinching ends together.
Grease two baking trays and place the finished braid or round on each. Cover with a towel and let rise for about 1 hour.
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Beat the remaining egg and brush a generous amount over each braid; sprinkle with poppy seeds.
Bake in preheated oven until golden brown, about 40 minutes. Cool on a wire rack for at least one hour before slicing.

review.reviewBody: This recipe was concise and an easy one. I wondered about when I separated into two pieces and kneaded each one , why not just knead the whole batch and then separate. If someone knows why do it this way please let me know. By the way it's amazingly delicious üòã! Everett
I added dried cranberries ... very good!
Stumbled upon this recipe several years ago and it has become a family favorite, it is wonderful bread.

I recently discovered through Ancestry that I have Jewish ancestors. To be honest, I was delighted by this. While I am in the tentative stages of learning more about the diversity of my heritage, I am most intrigued by this branch of my family. I went looking for a place to begin in regards to cuisine and happened upon this recipe. My family and friends were thrilled by the results. I did not have sesame seeds however I had 'everything bagel' seasoning. Very tasty. I have requests now to bake this for others. Next? Latkes üíú
Really like this recipe
Very tasty!
I sprinkled thyme and crushed red on top just before baking. It was amazing!
Amazing recipe, I make it all the time and everyone who tastes it said its the best bread ever! I highly highly recommend this recipe!
Made a 6 strand braid!

This recipe didn‚Äôt explain the technical side of making challah. It did taste and smell like Challah but the texture was all wrong. The braids all melted together into some strange Cronenberg-like shape. 

I didn‚Äôt understand the first part to ‚Äúbeat‚Äù the dry ingredients then fold it? Do I need a a spatula or a spoon or just my hands? The dough was sticky and then became so elastic that when I had to roll out the sections to braid after proofing they kept snapping back. Also asking to measure in diameter is silly. How long are these things supposed to be!? Lastly there was no mention to cover the bread to make sure the outside doesn't firm a hard crust. The crust i ended up with was that of a bagel and I had a blow out on the top. I think I'll look of another recipe elsewhere.
This recipe was perfect
We made a total of four round challahs and multiple smaller breads. Fun for the family and delicious. Only modification was the addition of three egg yolks along with one whole egg.
Excellent. My synagogue raved!
Perfect! Used bread flour, 1 egg + 2 egg yolks, upped honey to 1/2 c for a half recipe. Kneaded by hand and bread was super chewy with a wonderful aroma.
made this many times and it‚Äôs never failed me. a little dry after you set it out for a day or two (still need to get a bread box lol) but nothing a little pesto and olive oil can‚Äôt fix. 10/10

I think this is an absolute perfect base recipe for this bread. You can make it as it is and use it in so many ways, or modify for your purposes, which limits the usefulness. For instance, you can add more honey and eggs into the bread, brush honey with the egg on top, and it'll be a great treat, but not exactly usable for sandwiches. As it is, it's a great, subtle tasting sandwich bread that you can put anything on, like a brioche.

I made it exactly as written except for two minor changes: I rested the dough for 15 minutes after first mixing it to allow the flour to absorb more water, and I baked it for about 5 minutes longer to get it to a 195 internal temperature. The resting allowed me to only use about 7.5 cups of flour, making it as fluffy as possible, and at 45 minutes and 195 degrees, it was not burned, but was perfectly done. It was sticky, but 1/8 of a cup of flour during kneading was enough to keep it mostly unsticky. Eating it, made as it is written, the slightly eggy taste of the eggwash brushed on top makes it addictive. I honestly just kept eating more and more of it to try it with different things, from cheese to honey, to butter, to summer sausage, and it just enhanced everything.
I followed this recipe exactly and I think it‚Äôs the best bread I have ever had. Thank you Joan for this. I think I will probably reduce the temp or the time in the oven next time I make it.
I‚Äôve made this a few times, but always have to add an enormous amount of flour. By my math this recipe has a hydration of 75%! Challah is usually around 55%.

This was a great easy to follow recipe. Delicious and quite true to Brooklyn bakery Challah bread! I made no changes other than using Trader Joe‚Äôs Everything but the Bagel Sesame Seasoning Blend on top of the egg wash.

I made this Challah bread for the first time today, for Shabbat tomorrow night. I had to sneak a piece to make sure it was good enough to serve! I made two loaves, one plain egg bread, the other with cinnamon sugar. It is very good. I made a few adaptations due to other reviews. I used 3/4 cup honey, and added an extra egg white. I would not change the recipe I used today. However, It was a little overcooked at 375 for 30 minutes. I think I would bake it at 350 next time. And the bottom was really dark so I would use either a stone or put down parchment. Overall great texture. I am not much of a cook and I am pretty pleased with the outcome. And it looks lovely!!
This came out excellent on the first try. It is so soft on the inside with a nice crust on the outside. It is definitely a favourite.

my first time making challah and this was so easy to follow. it turned out great! very eggy and a little sweet, like a dense Hawaiian bread. (I'm not Jewish and I'd never had challah before, so this is my point of comparison.) It wasn't dry or tough! I'm not sure I ever got it smooth enough, but it looked and tasted great!
Yum yum!! Subbed out poppy seeds with oatmeal :)

I have made this challah so many times and I love it. This is the only recipe I have tried. Before this, I never made challah on my own. I am now going on almost a year making this. Love this recipe so much!!
Absolutely delicious. I am making it for the third time tonight.

For the longest time I thought Challah was just too hard to make. It would always come out dry and tough. This recipe came out perfectly! It was soft and delicious and I can now confidently serve home made Challah bread to my family!

I've made this twice now-- both times, the dough was VERY sticky and I needed to add more flour, resulting in a bit of a denser bread than I would have liked. I reduced bake time to 30 min and added wine-soaked raisins, a bit of extra honey, and 1 more egg. I am seeing suggestions to use just the egg yolk instead of the whole egg; this may be advisable to reduce the wetness of the dough. Color and the crust were lovely-- use parchment paper for easy clean-up.

It looks beautiful but its not as soft as maybe it should probably, i dont know why, i follow recipe to the dot. My needleling took extra long (about 1 hr) because I couldnt stop stickyness, i added so much flour to stop that. And i made the mistake on covering it completely with the damp towel so the though grew so much it ruined my towel.
Use traditional yeast
needs a lot more water than recommended! i put an extra cup and a half to make my bread

This is a great recipe! Easy, delicious, only two rises. I made it exactly as the recipe says, except for baking only about 33 minutes. I have been baking challah for 45 years and this is definitely one of the best.
Tasted like pretzel dough. Good thing I love pretzel
Great Challah! Only problem in my case was that I split the ingredients in half intending to make only one loaf, but ended up with a giant loaf that could have easily been split into two.

I made this recipe exactly as instructed, the only thing that I changed was the baking time. I have a convection oven (it bakes things faster) so I baked it for 25 minutes instead of 40 minutes. It turned out golden, perfectly fluffy and moist, and amazing! My family ate the whole loaf in one meal.

I cannot stop making these challahs! I follow the top reviewer suggestions using half the recipe, double the yeast, one egg and 3 egg yolks and 1/2 cup honey. I live in Philadelphia so I need to increase the proofing time, otherwise it‚Äôs too dense. I also cut the baking time to 30 minutes. It comes out as sweet, eggy challah that everyone adores! My waistline including!
Easy and delicious though not as "airy" as bakery-bought challah. NOTICE: "Servings" I didn't realize I could adjust the recipe to the serving size and made a whopping 30 serving challah!!

This recipe was okay, but the hydration was quite low. The challah was harder and drier than ones I‚Äôd bought at my local bakery and did not split into soft, flakey layers when I tore it. It tasted dry as well. After I doubled the eggs and added a bit more oil, the bread was much better.
Delicious!! At the stage of rolling the thirds of dough, I rolled them thinner than suggested and baked 5 mins less than suggested and it was perfect!
Play with the amount of water and flour. I might have added too much at first. Then I added a bit more water until I got the texture right
The taste is great but the baking time is way too long. Start checking your bread around 20 minutes.
Sometimes I use olive oil instead of vegetable oil. I also add Everything but the Bagel seasoning on top and it is delicious. These are great fresh but do not freeze well.

Didn't change a thing. This was fantastic! Before this, the only bread I ever made outside of a bread machine were quick breads. Doing it by hand definitely requires muscles and patience! Second time I made it using a mixing stand and that was much better on the hands. Either way, the bread was very good! Thank you for sharing!
Easy recipe! It was a tad sticky at the end so I added an additional 1/4 cup of flour. Like others said only took 20-30 mins. It‚Äôs not a very ‚Äúeggy‚Äù or overly sweet but delicious!!!

I have made it more than 5 times and it always taste good.

Here is my tip, don't add one cup at a time and then mix. It takes a while.

Add 7.5 cups of flour and knead. The other 0.5 use it if needed. It will save you time
I put foil on half way through to keep it from burning. Amazing.
Turned out just like mom made, perfection.
Great!!!!
Turned out great- made a LOT of challah!
Made this with my daughter and it turned out AMAZING. It was my first time making bread so I wasn't expecting much. this Challah brought me back to my fondest childhood memories!
I added a lot more flour

I love this bread I make it just like recipe. But since we are at 3800 ft above sea level I fell I add more flour. I have used 50/50 whole wheat and Unbleached flour and recipe turns out great. Foil over loaves at about 20 min will keep them from getting too brown. I have also braided bread and used bread pans. And that works . I think the braided bread us just pretty. And the honey is so much nicer than white sugar.
This was super delicious and not as hard to make as I thought. I made this for the first time ever and it turned out super good. Definitely would recommend if your patient enough to make bread!

The taste is great. I made this to the letter and no amount of kneading it could get rid of the stickiness. It ended up tasting more like a soft pretzel than any challah I've ever had. I'll try and a different recipe next time.
Thank you for the lovely recipe

Had to be carefull with the oven temperature, very old oven, loves to burn everything!
All went well
Came out bigger than expected!!
Keep a close eye on it while cooking. One of mine came out a little brown. But it‚Äôs me, not the recipe

Family winner even after I goofed it up a bit...very forgiving! I followed recipe except accidentally put that third egg in the dough...doh! It raised fine and tasted wonderful. For half the dough I made a braid, for the other half I made pull apart clover rolls. Both came out great. Would make again.
Great recipe. I will do Halla again. Thank you very much.

I've made this a few times now; extra egg yolks and honey turn it into something scrumptious! I use a silpat and parchment to keep the bottom from over browning, as my oven tends to run hot-I use the bottom oven tray and always tent after the first 20 min. It's usually done in approx. 30 min. Thanks, it's a keeper!

The final result was good. I liked the bread, although it was a little less sweet than I expected, which was no problem at all. It was my first experience making challah and I noticed that there was either too much liquid or too little flour. The dough was sticky even after kneading it for quite some time. I had to add a lot more flour and I braided it while still sticky. Also, it did not need 40 minutes of baking. I'm glad I removed it about 10 minutes earlier, otherwise it would be dry if not burned. Overall, it's a recipe I want to keep.
Super easy and fun to make. And it is delicious!
I usually don‚Äôt post reviews unless is very very good or very bad. I‚Äôm so excited about this bread it came out perfect. We added some poppy seeds and tasted very good
The bottoms seemed to darken very fast . I had to adjust the temperature of my oven. It does not freeze very well.

This bread was so so sticky - ended up using more than 10 cups of flour to finally have it all come together. Then it cooked wayyyy faster than the recipe says and came out very crunchy which Challah shouldn't do. I recommend making changes to this recipe or finding a different one. After reading through some of the 5 star reviews I found that most of them had made changes to the recipe.
My Jewish ex husband used to love my challah!

I've come back to this recipe multiple times and have founds ways to perfect it for my taste. I also half the recipe, so I am going off those proprotions.
I add two eggs yolks, and extra 1/4c of honey, and a dash extra of salt. I also tend to measure out an extra two cups of flour, because I find the dough remains quite sticky and takes a lot more than the recipe states. I may play with increasing the amount of yeast soon, as I noticed another reviewer did.
It was super simple and super good! If you need a Challah recipe, USE THIS ONE!! It is awesome. I didn‚Äôt change anything, and it turned out great!
I made it exactly as the directions described and it turned out wonderful. Delicious! I would take 5 minutes off the baking time though.

First type of bread I made in years turned very nice
I will make this again

+ ~2tbsp H2O depending on humidity at 5300' elevation.
Great flavor and texture.

I love this recipe. It's similar to Wegman's except a little eggier which I love. This recipe is also very good for messing around with to perfect your own preferences. You can use cake flour to make it super airy if you wanted to. This is good with warm butter - Or you can use a little whole milk in place of the water for super nice tearing if you are using it for Shabbat. So many possibilities. Great recipe. It's the only one I'd use. You can pretty much do whatever you want to it and it turns out perfect.
Loved it, didn't use quite as much honey and it still turned out wonderful. Instead of poppy seeds I sprinkled Himalayan salt on top and it was great
Excellent recipe.
This came out beautifully and I had never made challah before. I incorporated a few tips from another baker to make it a bit sweeter and eggier.
Lasts for days without going stale, and feeds more people than you would think

First bread I have made that pretty much came out much better than expected! Took the advice from a few of the other reviews and used what I thought was the best of them. Activated the yeast with some sugar and water first then added the egg, salt, oil, honey and then added the flour cup by cup. Baked a total of 40 minutes at 375.

I found this recipe easy to follow and the bread was delicious! Dough was nice to work with. I did make some of the changes as suggested by other reviewers (used milk, one egg and 3 egg yolks) I have plans to make this a regular bake in our house.

This is delicious! Love the texture, and the dough was beautiful to work with. I made a half batch then slip that into two to make two mini loaves. Made one with cinnamon swirl and one chai spiced with a orange glaze. Awaiting the final verdict from the family ( I made these at around 2 am) but I'm sure they'll love it!
I made it this afternoon and it's wonderful. I cut the recipe in half to make 1 loaf instead and I highly doubt that loaf will last the night!
We made this with unbleached whole wheat flour. Turned out great! Also sprinkled with "everything bagel" seasoning. Will make again.
Great tasting bread, followed the recipe!
I make it for shabbat!!! It was a blast. Thank you for the recipe.
Made 3 times already. On the third try, used 3 cups of water instead. Dough came out perfectly hydrated for 8 cups of flour.

Amazing! Star dish of my dinner! I followed other suggestions of other and halved the recipe (made one loaf) and used 1 egg plus three yolks and a half a cup of honey. I kept the yeast at 1 and a half teaspoons. Finished with an egg wash and large flakes of salt. When it was done baking a drizzled honey on top of the challah. As traditional challahs are served I left it whole for everyone to pull off their own pieces at the table. THANK YOU FOR THE RECIPE! I should also note that I used my regular kitchen aid which really helped. Whisk for wet ingredients and switched to the hook once I started adding the flour - life saver.
I made challah for the first time in my life. It was very easy and the results were phenomenal! Five stars!
Excellent recipe. Can't think of anything i'd change. was a big hit with the family too.

Followed directions perfectly. Looked great after about 25 min in oven - nice and brown. Actually, it looked done! Recipe said 40 min so I lowered temp to 325 and covered with foil. After about 6 min. I started to smell it burning. Black on bottom. Only in for 31 min! I used two non-stick pans. Oven is only a little over a year old and has never had an issue.
Mine was still a bit doughy after 40 minutes!

I found this to be a great recipe! Just a couple tweaks. I used 1 and a half packets of active dry yeast, 1 and a half cups of whole milk with 1 cup of water, used a full cup of honey, one egg and 2 yolks. I also ended up using close to 2 extra cups of flour to get the right consistency. I mixed a bit of honey with the egg wash and basted it again 20mins into baking, and finished it off with the last 10mins. It was absolutely perfect this way!

This was my first ever attempt at bread, and baking in general, and it came out great! Fantastic, and simple! I‚Äôve made it three times now, so here are my obligatory tips and substitutions: 1/2 cup of honey, a whole pack of yeast, 1 whole egg and two yolks without whites for the dough. The whites get used for the wash. Happy baking!

Okay, I love this recipe. I had never made challah bread before, and it was a good project. Easy, fun, and really beautiful. Because it made two loaves, we can make ( and freeze). French toast.

Here is something about which I feel inclined to warn you. DO NOT ADD ANY WHEAT FLOUR. I ran out of white flour, so ended up mixing a cup or two. The wheat taste took over the lovely challah flavor. Be careful about that.
It came out great! Looks beautiful and tastes delicious but I forgot to add the salt! Going to make it again tomorrow!!!

This took awhile to make because there was sooo much dough to work with. I could have easily made three or four loaves with how large these two loaves were. I've never made this bread before and my family loved it! Thank you!
made this for rosh hashana, it was perfect
This was an easy recipe and great just as is! On one loaf I topped part of the loaf with ‚Äúeverything but the bagel‚Äù seasoning and on the other loaf I incorporated raisins. Yum!!
Absolutely loved how easy this bread was to make. It made a large bread. Next time I will divide into 2 loaves

I will definitely make again! May add a bit more honey to make it a bit more sweeter however we dipped it in some honey Friday dinner and that solved it. Super easy and I definitely encourage you to watch the video I probably went by the video more than the instructions and it turned out beautiful!
Turned out good on first try!
Followed this exactly. Turned out perfect. Going to make again definitely
